docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA - Before American steel mills went silent, Lowry Graham's dad labored in one for four decades. A high school graduate, he was more educated than most of his co-workers. He liked his job, became a foreman and was proud of it.
docs.abstract: In Philadelphia, some people are willing to scrape by in the city for a sense of community and more free time.
docs.snippet: In Philadelphia, some people are willing to scrape by in the city for a sense of community and more free time.

docs.lead_paragraph: So much for "post-race." The Times's Peter Baker writes that four months after President Obama's inauguration, identity politics is "back with a vengeance." He continues:
docs.abstract: From Texas schools to Washington's halls of power, any declaration of a "post-racial" period seems to be premature.
docs.snippet: From Texas schools to Washington's halls of power, any declaration of a "post-racial" period seems to be premature.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two Senate committee chairmen issued a joint statement on Saturday saying they would "seek common ground on health reform legislation," despite reports that they disagreed on the shape of a new public health insurance plan that many Democrats want to create.

headline.main: Kennedy and Baucus 'Seek Common Ground' on Health Care Legislation

docs.abstract: Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Max Baucus issued a statement saying they would "seek common ground" on health reform legislation a day after The New York Times reported that the two Democrats disagreed over the details of a government-sponsored plan.
docs.snippet: Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Max Baucus issued a statement saying they would "seek common ground" on health reform legislation a day after The New York Times reported that the two Democrats disagreed over the details of a government-sponsored plan.
